author: curiousapple
content:
Hi Guys,
Abhishek this side
Have one doubt

What is the reason of limiting stake of validator to 32 ETH ?

No more No less

author: potuz
content:
No more: a very large staking capital in one validator could take control of a committee.
No less: a very small staking capital would make it cheaper to attack the network.

author: albusdompeldorius
content:
> No less: a very small staking capital would make it cheaper to attack the network.

How so? Wouldn't you still need 51%, 67% or whatever of the total staked amount to attack the network?

author: albusdompeldorius
content: IIUIC, the reason not to lower it has to do with limiting the work needed for signature aggregation.

author: potuz
content:
Yeah by attack I meant the cost of verification. Probably bad choice of words. The original rationale for those numbers I think comes from
https://medium.com/@VitalikButerin/parametrizing-casper-the-decentralization-finality-time-overhead-tradeoff-3f2011672735

author: m.kalinin
content: There is also an elaboration in the Serenity design rationale doc, https://notes.ethereum.org/@vbuterin/rkhCgQteN?type=view#Why-32-ETH-validator-sizes, which refers to the post mentioned above

author: curiousapple
content:
How does it solve multiple identities ?

Like if I stake 320
Or I stake 32 with 10 diff accounts

author: protolambda
content: Above 32 eth, stake is not effective. The balance is there, but it doesn't count towards voting. So you have to split it between validators to increase effect on the network, and earn rewards with it.

author: potuz
content: If you have many validators and they happen to be included in the same committee you may take control

author: potuz
content: But if you only have one, then every time you are in control of the committee

author: protolambda
content: right, the protocol requires stake to be divided into multiple validators, to make the random shuffling of validators between committees more effective
